facts.text: Contractor entered into contract with Dominion of India through Additional Chief Engineer CPWD on 1 November 1945 for supply of bricks.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us, whom it will be companyvenient to call the companytractor, entered into a companytract with the Dominion of India through an Additional Chief Engineer of the C.P.W.D. on 1-11-1945 for the supply of bricks to the C.P.W.D., a

facts.text: Disputes referred to Superintending Engineer arbitrator on 21 January 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, there was a reference on 21-1-1949 and an award followed on 8-5-1949.

facts.text: Arbitrator made award on 8 May 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, there was a reference on 21-1-1949 and an award followed on 8-5-1949. It was filed in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad, and the companytractor prayed that it be accepted and that a decree be passed in terms of it.

facts.text: Decree passed in terms of award on 18 March 1950 by Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractors application was registered as a suit under section 20 2  of the Act and a decree was passed in terms of the award on 18-3-1950.

facts.text: Union of India replaced Dominion of India as defendant after Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: By that time the Constitution had companye into force and the Union of India replaced the Dominion of India as a defendant. The Union of India filed an appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Union of India appealed to High Court Patna.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India filed an appeal to the High Court. The appeal was allowed in part.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal in part.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was allowed in part. The companytractor thereupon appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Contract for supply of 2-1/2 crores pucca bricks with delivery schedule: 30 lacs by 25-1-46, 50 lacs by 25-2-46, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract was for the supply of 2-1/2 crores of pucca bricks which bad to be delivered according to the following schedule- 30 lacs by 25-1-46 50 lacs by 25-2-46 55 lacs by 25-3-46 55 lacs by 25-4-46 60 lacs by 25-5-46.

facts.text: CPWD failed to remove baked bricks ready for delivery, causing jam and accumulation of 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain.

anchor.surface_text: At a certain stage of the companytract the P.W.D. failed to remove the baked bricks which were ready for delivery and removal. This caused a jam in the kilns and prevented the companytractor from placing a fresh stock of unburnt bricks in the kilns, and

facts.text: Contractor claimed Rs. 75,900 for 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain under item 5.

anchor.surface_text: In the 5th head of claim the companytractor claimed Rs. 75,900 as the price of 88 lacs of katcha bricks that were destroyed by rain.

facts.text: Clause 6 of agreement: department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Government relied on additional clause 6 of the agreement which is in these terms The department will number entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

facts.text: Arbitrator awarded Rs. 64,075 to contractor under item 5, holding clause 6 not absolving department from contract obligations.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator held that this clause was number meant to absolve the department from carrying out their part of the companytract and so he awarded the companytractor Rs. 64,075 under this head.

facts.text: Supreme Court held arbitrator erred in law on interpretation of clause 6; government not liable for katcha bricks loss.

anchor.surface_text: We are clear that the arbitrator went wrong in law. ... There can therefore be numberdoubt that the arbitrator was wrong in his law. His companystruction of the terms of the companytract was at fault.

facts.text: Contractor claimed Rs. 51,495 under item 8 for additional wages due to non-supply of ration and cloth.

facts.text: Contractor claimed interest Rs. 27,665 under item 17 at 6% for 16 months from 1-1-48.

anchor.surface_text: The last item in dispute in this appeal is claim No. 17 about interest. The statement of claims sets out Item 17-Interest on the amount of money involved in this claim at the rate of Rs. 6 percent.Rs. 27,665.

facts.text: Arbitrator awarded interest on awarded amounts.

anchor.surface_text: I therefore award interest at 6 for 16 months on the total amount of the awards given i.e., Rs. 17,363.

facts.text: Supreme Court held arbitrator had no power to award interest; conditions of Interest Act not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Not one of these elements is present, so the arbitrator erred in law in thinking that he had the power to allow interest simply because he thought the demand was reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the other appeal, Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954. ... The High Court was right in dismissing the claims made under the heads in dispute here.

holdings.text: The arbitrator went wrong in law in his construction of clause 6 of the contract; clause 6 expressly relieves the Union Government of all liability for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Government relied on additional clause 6 of the agreement which is in these terms The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever. The arbitrator held that this clause was not meant to absolve the department from carrying out their part of the contract and so he awarded the contractor Rs. 64,075 under this head. We are clear that the arbitrator went wrong in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 6 is an express term agreed by parties foreseeing risks like rain; arbitrator misapplied by implying exception for department fault; supported by Contract Act s.73 duty to mitigate and remoteness of damage.

holdings.text: Where an error of law is apparent on the face of the arbitration award and no question of law was specifically referred to the arbitrator, the court may interfere under s.16(1)(c) of the Arbitration Act 1940.

anchor.surface_text: His construction of the terms of the contract was at fault. The question now arises whether his decision on this point is final despite it being wrong in law. In India this question is governed by section 16 1 c of the Arbitration Act of 1940 which empowers a Court to remit an award for reconsideration where an objection to the legality of the award is apparent upon the face of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes specific reference of law (binding) from incidental decision (reviewable); arbitrator bound by law, not equity; follows English precedents like Absalom and Privy Council cases.

holdings.text: No specific question of law, such as construction of clause 6, was referred to the arbitrator; incidental reference in pleadings insufficient to oust court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We have next to see whether the arbitrator was specifically asked to construe clause 6 of the contract or any part of the contract, or whether any question of law was specifically referred. We stress the word specifically because parties who make a reference to arbitration have the right to insist that the tribunal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference requires mutual assent or court order under s.20(4); contractor's unilateral argument on clause 6 in claim not specific reference; follows Absalom and Heyman precedents.

holdings.text: Error of law re clause 6 is apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: Simply because the matter was referred to incidentally in the pleadings and arguments in support of, or against, the general issue about liability for damages, that is not enough to clothe the arbitrator with exclusive jurisdiction on a point of law. The next question is whether the error is apparent on the face

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award quotes clause but ignores its absolute terms; arbitrator's opinion that it does not absolve department contradicts express wording.

holdings.text: No implied or collateral contractual obligation on government to supply rations and cloth; contractor signed contract without acceptance of proposal.

anchor.surface_text: It is an error in law to deduce from this that there was acceptance of the fresh proposal. On the contrary, the legal conclusion is that the new suggestion was dropped and that the contractor was content to accept the contract as it was without this condition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract signed post-proposal without reply or inclusion; one-sided hope not binding; rationing under provincial control, not Dominion; no evidence or admission supports finding.

holdings.text: Rations and cloth claim, being collateral contract, not covered by arbitration clause 14 which is confined to the written contract.

anchor.surface_text: especially as reference was made to section 9 of the Contract Act, then that is not a contract to which the arbitration clause can apply. Wide though it is, clause 14 is confined to any matter relating to the written contract and if ration and cloth are not covered by the written contract, they are not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 14 covers disputes 'arising out of or relating to the contract'; separate implied/collateral terms outside scope; follows Heyman v Darwins.

holdings.text: Arbitrator had no power to award interest; conditions of Interest Act 1839 not satisfied (no certain debt, written contract for interest, demand).
